name: Paella
description: A fragrant rice‑based dish from Valencia, often topped with seafood like shrimp, squid, mussels, and flavored with paprika, saffron, stock, garlic, tomatoes, and wine.
notes: Seafood paella is the most iconic, but you can also get vegetarian or mixed versions.
Often cooked for large groups—best shared.

name: Croquetas
description: Creamy breadcrumbs‑coated bites made with béchamel mixed with ham, potato, or shrimp—served as tapas or larger rations.
notes: Ham croquetas are the classic; try shrimp or mushroom for variety.
They’re delicious when freshly fried and still creamy inside.

name: Fideuà
description: A seafood dish similar to paella, but made with short vermicelli-like noodles instead of rice. Typically cooked in a wide pan with cuttlefish, shrimp, mussels, and squid ink or fish stock.
notes: Best enjoyed freshly made near the coast.
Often served with a side of allioli (garlic mayo).
Can be black (with squid ink) or golden depending on region.

name: Patatas Bravas
description: Fried potato cubes topped with spicy bravas tomato sauce and aioli—crispy, fluffy, and umami‑packed.
notes: Each region (and even restaurant) makes the sauce differently.
Often served as a shareable snack with drinks.

name: Esqueixada de Bacalao
description: A refreshing Catalan salad made with shredded salt cod, tomatoes, onions, olives, and drizzled with olive oil. Often garnished with red or green peppers and sometimes hard-boiled egg.
notes: Name comes from the Catalan word 'esqueixar', meaning 'to tear by hand'.
Usually served cold — ideal for hot weather.
Pairs well with crusty bread or olives.
Traditionally made with salt cod (bacalao) that has been soaked and shredded.

name: Jamón Ibérico
description: Thinly‑sliced, dry‑cured Iberian ham from acorn‑fed black pigs—served as a classic charcuterie staple.
notes: Often served with bread or olives.
Look for ‘pata negra’ (pure Iberico) for maximum quality.

name: Bomba
description: A Barceloneta specialty: deep‑fried potato and meat ball, often spicy—and perfect for tapas.
notes: Spicy sauce inside is a signature element.
Serve with aioli to balance heat.

name: Gazpacho
description: An ice‑cold soup made with blended tomatoes, peppers, garlic, vinegar, olive oil—and sometimes bread—for a refreshing summer starter.
notes: Best served ice-cold in summer.
Can be garnished with chopped veggies or croutons.

name: Escalivada
description: A Catalan roasted vegetable dish with eggplant, bell peppers, and onions drizzled in olive oil—served warm or cold with bread.
notes: Simple but flavorful — highlight seasonal produce.
Pairs well with grilled fish or meat.

name: Spanish Cheese Platter
description: A selection of Spanish cheeses—Manchego, Idiazábal, Mahón, Roncal—served with accompaniments like nuts or honey.
notes: Ask for local artisan cheeses for best flavor.
Pair with sweet wine or honey for contrast.

name: Pa amb Tomaquet
description: Toasted bread rubbed with garlic and ripe tomato, drizzled with olive oil and salt; a simple Catalan classic.
notes: Adjust garlic and tomato to taste.
Great accompaniment to any meal.

name: Padrón Peppers
description: Small green peppers blistered in oil and sprinkled with salt—most are mild, but occasionally one surprises with heat.
notes: Fun to eat — you never know which will be spicy!
Best when blistered and slightly charred.

name: Esqueixada
description: A Catalan salt‑cod salad torn by hand, mixed with tomatoes, onions, olives, and olive oil—light and zesty.
notes: Very light and fresh—great on hot days.
Traditionally eaten with bread or potatoes.

name: Tortilla de Patatas
description: A thick Spanish omelet made with potatoes (and sometimes onions)—comforting and a common staple across Spain.
notes: Can be served warm or at room temperature.
Some regions add onion and others don’t — try both!

name: Arròs Negre
description: A savory black rice dish cooked with squid or cuttlefish and colored with their ink, giving it a deep umami flavor and striking appearance.
notes: Often garnished with alioli (garlic mayonnaise) on top or on the side.
Best enjoyed fresh with a glass of white wine or cava.
Not to be confused with paella, though it's similar in preparation.

name: Chipirones
description: Small squid, typically grilled or fried, served whole and often dressed simply with olive oil, garlic, and parsley. A popular tapa or seafood dish in coastal Spain.
notes: Can be served a la plancha (grilled) or fritos (fried).
Freshness is key — best near the coast.
Sometimes served with lemon or a side of alioli.

name: Chorizo
description: A cured or semi-cured pork sausage seasoned with smoked paprika and garlic, known for its deep red color and bold, smoky flavor. Commonly sliced and served on its own or incorporated into a variety of Spanish dishes.
whenToEat: Any meal; common in tapas and stews
notes: Available in spicy (picante) and mild (dulce) varieties.
Can be eaten cured (like salami) or cooked in dishes like fabada and tortilla.
Pairs well with Manchego cheese and red wine.

name: Crema Catalana
description: A traditional Catalan dessert similar to crème brûlée, made with milk, egg yolks, sugar, and flavored with lemon zest and cinnamon. It features a caramelized sugar crust on top.
notes: Usually served cold with the sugar crust freshly torched.
Lighter than French crème brûlée due to milk instead of cream.
Often eaten on Saint Joseph’s Day (March 19) in Catalonia.

name: Churros
description: Fried dough pastries, often sprinkled with sugar and served with a thick hot chocolate for dipping. Popular as a breakfast or late-night treat.
notes: Traditionally enjoyed with thick Spanish hot chocolate.
Best eaten fresh and warm.
Churros in Barcelona tend to be thinner and crispier compared to other regions.
Often enjoyed after a night out, especially on weekends.

name: Mel i Mató
description: A simple Catalan dessert made of soft unsalted cheese (mató) topped with honey. Light, creamy, and traditional.
notes: Often served chilled with fresh local honey.
Mató cheese is similar to ricotta but lighter and less salty.
Great after a rich meal — light and not overly sweet.

name: Flan
description: A caramel custard dessert made with eggs, milk, and sugar, topped with a layer of soft caramel. Found throughout Spain.
notes: Sometimes infused with citrus zest or vanilla.
Served chilled, often with whipped cream or a cherry.
One of the most common desserts in Spain — classic and comforting.

name: Ensaimada
description: A soft, coiled pastry dusted with powdered sugar, originally from Mallorca but found in Catalonia. Often filled with cream, custard, or pumpkin jam.
notes: Best enjoyed fresh in the morning.
Classic version is plain, but fillings are popular too.
Pairs wonderfully with coffee or hot chocolate.

name: Cava
description: A sparkling wine from Catalonia, made using traditional methods similar to Champagne. It is known for its fine bubbles and balanced flavor, ranging from dry to sweet.
notes: Often served at celebrations and with tapas.
Brut Nature is the driest type — popular among locals.
Pairs well with seafood, jamón, and salty snacks.
Made primarily with Macabeo, Parellada, and Xarel·lo grapes.

name: Sangria
description: A popular Spanish punch made with red wine, chopped fruit (like oranges and apples), orange juice, and a splash of brandy or soda water.
notes: Variations include white sangria (sangría blanca) made with white wine.
Often served chilled in pitchers for groups.
Tourist favorite, though locals may opt for simpler drinks like tinto de verano.

name: Orxata (Horchata de Chufa)
description: A sweet, milky drink made from soaked and ground tiger nuts, served chilled. Especially popular in Valencia and Catalonia during summer.
notes: Often paired with fartons (sugar-glazed pastry sticks).
Naturally dairy-free and gluten-free.
Should be consumed fresh — it spoils quickly without refrigeration.

name: Clara
description: A refreshing mix of beer and lemon soda (like Fanta Limón), popular as a light, summery alternative to straight beer.
notes: Known as a 'shandy' in English-speaking countries.
Preferred on hot days or with tapas.
Low alcohol content makes it a popular midday drink.

name: Carajillo
description: A bold mix of espresso coffee and liquor (typically brandy or rum), served hot. A classic pick-me-up drink in Spain.
whenToEat: After meals or as a digestif
notes: Sometimes flamed with sugar and lemon peel for extra flavor.
Common after lunch or dinner.
A Spanish twist on coffee with alcohol — not to be confused with Irish coffee.

name: Vermouth (Vermut)
description: An aromatized, fortified wine infused with herbs and spices. Typically served over ice with an olive or orange slice, often with a splash of soda.
notes: Weekend vermouth hour is a Barcelona tradition.
Pairs well with olives, anchovies, and chips.
Homemade house blends vary by bar.

name: Jerez Cocktail (Sherry Cocktail)
description: A cocktail made from dry or sweet sherry (Jerez wine), often mixed with orange bitters, citrus zest, or other ingredients to enhance its nutty character.
notes: Dry fino or amontillado sherry is used for crisp versions.
Sweet oloroso or cream sherry for dessert-style cocktails.
Jerez is the Spanish name for sherry and a wine region.

name: Orujo
description: A strong pomace brandy made by distilling grape skins, stems, and seeds left over from winemaking. Served as a digestif, often chilled.
notes: Sometimes infused with herbs (orujo de hierbas) or cream (crema de orujo).
Can be over 40% alcohol — drink in moderation.
Considered the Galician cousin to Italian grappa.
